Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: MOEX Offshore 2007 LLC agreed to settle its liability in the Deepwater Horizon oil spill in a settlement with the United States valued at $90 million. Approximately $45 million of the $90 million settlement was in the form of penalties or expedited environmental projects.

NAICS Translation: 325320: Pesticide and Other Agricultural Chemical Manufacturing
Info Source: Extracted from a download of OSHA's Enforcment Data downloaded on 3/02/2022, available at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_catalogs.php

Description: MOEX agreed to pay $25 million to five states to settle litigation relating to the Deepwater Horizon oil spill. The breakdown was as follows: $6.75 million to Louisiana; $5 million each to  Alabama, Florida and Mississippi; and $3.25 million to Texas. This was all part of a larger $90 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-moex-offshore-2007-llc.
Settlement concerning the 2010 Deepwater Horizon oil spill. MOEX had a 10 percent working interest in the offshore drilling vessel.
Info Source: Deepwater Horizon Investor to Pay Penalties for 2010 Oil Spill, Fund Texas Gulf Coast Restoration, States News Service, February 24, 2012 (via Nexis).
Contained in data obtained from the agency on October 6, 2020 in response to an open records request.

Description: Louisiana share of joint State/Federal Settlement.
Notes: Penalty includes $6,500,000 on Beneficial Environmental Projects.

Agency: South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control
